titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Johnson and Campbell Family Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:31

did.unittitle: Johnson and Campbell family papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers contain correspondence, legal documents, maps, and printed material by or relating to Guy Johnson and his experiences as Superintendent of Indian Affairs during the American Revolution, as well as documentation of his efforts regarding claims on his confiscated property in the United States. Series I holds Johnson's papers, which include correspondence with family members and British military officers Guy Carleton and Thomas Gage. Also present are two printed almanacs and two autograph manuscript journals recording Johnson's activities and voyages between Quebec and England, and New York and Quebec. Documents in the papers include several on parchment recording Johnson's services to the crown and his lands in New York, a list of accounts with Joseph Brant, and a manuscript record titled "Return of Services performed by the Indians of Colonel Guy Johnson's Department" which details "the Killed, wounded, etc. & damages done to the Rebels from the beginning of the Year 1780 to the end of 1781." Series II holds material related to Johnson's family in Ireland and Great Britain, in particular records of his son-in-law Colin Campbell and daughters Mary Johnson Campbell and Julia Johnson, documenting their involvement in the settlement of Guy Johnson's estate and their efforts regarding his confiscated property. Correspondence holds letters from banker Thomas Coutts, and several petitions the family submitted to the commissioners for American claims. Also present are personal letters to Colin Campbell from others, including British general Sir William Howe, concerning his military career.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Company (Sotheby's London sale, 2000 July 13, lot 200) on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund and the Chandler White and Philena Pennell Smith Acquisitions Fund, 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Johnson and Campbell Family Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Johnson and Campbell Family Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization.
Descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Guy Johnson Papers, 1757-1789. II. Campbell Family Papers, 1780-1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers contain correspondence, legal documents, maps, and printed material by or relating to Guy Johnson and his experiences as Superintendent of Indian Affairs during the American Revolution, as well as documentation of his efforts to regain his confiscated property in the United States. Series I holds Johnson's papers, which includes correspondence with family members and British military officers Guy Carleton and Thomas Gage, Also present are two printed almanacs and two autograph manuscript journals recording Johnson's activities and voyages between Quebec and England, and New York and Quebec. A group of documents include several on parchment recording Johnson's services to the crown and his lands in New York, and a manuscript record titled "Return of Services performed by the Indians of Colonel Guy Johnson's Department" which details "the Killed, wounded, etc. & damages done to the Rebels from the beginning of the Year 1780 to the end of 1781." Series II holds material related to Johnson's family in Ireland and Great Britain, in particular records of his son-in-law Colin Campbell and daughters Mary Johnson Campbell and Julia Johnson, documenting their involvement in the settlement of Guy Johnson's estate and their efforts regarding his confiscated property. Correspondence includes letters from banker Thomas Coutts, and several petitions the family submitted to the Commissioners for American Claims. The earliest document in the collection is an autograph manuscript copy of the Patent of Creation awarded to Sir William Johnson (1757) and the latest is a photographic reproduction (1918) of a 1772 manuscript survey of Johnson's lands in New York; the original manuscript map, drawn by William Johnson's surveyor Robert Picken, is also in the collection.

bioghist.head: Guy Johnson (approximately 1740-1788)
bioghist.p: Guy Johnson was born in Ireland, and arrived in the Province of New York in 1756 to became a secretary to his uncle, Sir William Johnson, the British Superintendent of Indian Affairs of the northern colonies. Johnson succeeded his uncle as superintendent in 1774, and also served as a colonel in the Tryon County (New York) militia and a member of the provincial New York Assembly. In 1763 Guy Johnson married his cousin Mary ("Polly") Johnson (died 1775), the daughter of Sir William Johnson; the couple had five daughters, two of whom, Mary and Julia, lived to adulthood. Johnson resigned his superintendency in 1782 and returned to England to seek restitution of his New York property that had been confiscated by the United States government. He died in London on March 5, 1788.

did.unittitle: Guy Johnson Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Correspondence, Journals, Documents, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains letters between Guy Johnson and his daughter and son-in-law Mary and Colin Campbell, daughter Julia Johnson, brother-in-law Daniel Claus, brother-in-law (and cousin) John Johnson, and uncle (and father-in-law) William Johnson. Also present are four journals and almanacs documenting Johnson's activities, including voyages between Quebec and England, and New York and Quebec, and petitions and other papers related to Johnson's career, remuneration, and claims on his property in the United States. Other Papers holds documents seemingly unrelated to Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II holds material related to Johnson's family in Ireland and Great Britain, in particular records of his son-in-law Colin Campbell and daughters Mary Johnson Campbell and Julia Johnson, documenting their involvement in the settlement of Guy Johnson's estate and their claims against his confiscated property. Correspondence includes letters from banker Thomas Coutts, and several petitions the family submitted to the Commissioners for American Claims. Also present are personal letters to Colin Campbell from others, including the British general Sir William Howe, concerning his military career.
